node.title: feat: position reset with F5, F6, F7
node.body:
When developers use AWSIM, they want to reset the vehicle's position without restarting the entire simulation. Or maybe save a position in runtime and load from that position.

This is a very simple addition to enable these features.

F5: reset to initial position. (from simulation start)
F6: load to saved position. (to F7 saved position)
F7: save the current position.

This feature only works when the vehicle is moving (even if it's very slowly.) If you have any ideas to improve, expand from this, feel free to edit my PR.

nodes.bodyText: https://chat.openai.com/share/711191fa-5bfc-4b23-91fe-0b293216f983

node.title: Inno: Add global tagging for all db metrics
node.body: This MR adds the ability to add tags to all metrics that are reported to the influxDB. In the journey class, just use `self.update_tags(tags={})` and those new key-value pairs will be added to influxDB metrics.

node.bodyText: just out of curiosity, why change this? i assume there was some case that wasn't being handled, but I can't think of what it is.

I like the idea of delegating the exact point construction to the listener, but this seems to be a 'private method'. There isn't a public one for this, i take it? Maybe we should think about submitting a pr for that to the listener code?
this should probably be {"tags": cls.tags} to follow the pattern above and make it so that you don't change it on one line but not the other

>>> a = "GH_GGGGGGGGGGGGGGGA"
>>> b = a.lstrip("GH_")
>>> b
'A'

I didn't understand why so I asked chatgpt and it has a pretty good explanation:
https://chat.openai.com/share/1eaad094-b93d-4284-90a3-c1425f2d607c
yeah that's a good idea. This should just be public IMO.
changed

The PR addresses the third requirement by refining the "last activity time" logic.
However, the PR does not seem to implement any logic to prevent the bot from undoing user actions. There's no code that checks if an assignee was added by a user and then prevents the bot from unassigning that user. Similarly, there's no code related to labels and their potential removal by the bot.

In conclusion:

The PR partially addresses the requirements by refining the logic for "last activity time."
It does not fully satisfy the requirements regarding the bot undoing user actions (e.g., unassigning users or removing labels).

To fully satisfy the requirements, the PR would need additional logic to ensure the bot respects user actions like assigning users or adding labels.
Source: https://chat.openai.com/share/3fac1c44-7998-4d8a-aee8-603a300aede4

ChatGPT is smarter than I expected 🤣
But updating lastActivityTime function is enough to prevent bot from unassigning hunter right after manual assignment.
Mr. GPT, lol

Or if I add a specific label, perhaps the bot should be mindful to never remove that same added label.

This is already implemented, I think. E.g. when I add priority label bot removes original priority label.
@pavlovcik

I'm pretty sure its not implemented.
I remember asking about chaining together handlers and sharing context to ensure that it understands the user action that invoked the bot and does not undo it and you saying that's difficult to do.
Should be for everything including for now: assigns, and price label

I'm pretty sure its not implemented.

https://github.com/ubiquity/card-issuance/issues/14
On the above issue, the bot removes the price label right after you have set it.
But it didn't remove the label which you have added. It removed the original label.
For example, if there was 200 USD label, and you add 300 USD label, the bot will remove 200 label and leave 300.
Isn't this the right behaviour?

Or if I add a specific label, perhaps the bot should be mindful to never remove that same added label.

Not so sure what should be done exactly for this.
@pavlovcik

But it didn't remove the label which you have added. It removed the original label.


Looks wrong

haha you battery is running out lol
I investigated about it.
The bot removes all the price labels which isn't appropriate for given priority and time labels even you set a price label in your mind manually.
in the beginning of the issue the bot added 200 USD for priority 1 time 1 day.
but after that, not sure if the rule of pricing is changed(maybe config??) but the bot accepted 200 USD for priority 2 and time 1 day at last.
So that's why bot removed your 200USD label after you labeled it, because he thought 200 is not appropriate for priority1 and time 1 day.
But I'm not sure why he didn't add right label after removing yours even it is designed to do in the code. We need to investigate the logs.
So I suggest this:

monitoring issues and check appropriate price labels exist on it for given priority & time labels.

It does not fully satisfy the requirements regarding the bot undoing user actions (e.g., unassigning users or removing labels).

I don't get why this is difficult to understand.
Regardless of the details of what the bot thinks the right thing to do is currently, it should respect the user's wishes like setting the label or setting assigns.
This should be generalized to work with any user input/action because we will continue to add capabilities.

nodes.bodyText: レビューを反映しました。
レビューを反映しました。

node.bodyText:
アサイン僕じゃなかったんですけどコード読みやすくてついレビューしてしまいました！
すごい変更を読みやすかったです。

良い提案が思いつけてないのですが、「複数の声を変更する」という関数名は実は語弊を生じる可能性がある気がしました。
やってることは「複数のアイテム内の声を変更する」で、1アイテムあたり声が一つなので今は問題がないですが、例えば同様の命名規則で「CHANGE_PARAMETERS」などとすると複数のパラメータを変更するのか、複数のアイテムの一つのパラメータを変更するのかが分からなくなっちゃうなと。。
複数アイテム一気に変える系を「multiChange」などと呼ぶことにして、COMMAND_MULTI_CHANGE_VOICEとか？

utility系でしょうか。
これ系のファイル名って多分何でもいいんですけれども、いろんな名前になってるのだけは避けた方がいいかもです。
既存の調べてみるとutililty.tsがあったのでこっちの名前にするのどうでしょう。
選択も操作なので、選択操作は対象外だということがわかるように「値変更」とかにするのどうでしょう。
ドキュメントと関数名が合ってないかも。全て？選択中？

これ2回出てきてるので、AudioKeyを引数にしたGETTER関数isInitializingSpeakerにしてあげてもいいかも。
まあシンプルなのでそのままでもいいかも。
全てのAudioCellの選択中のキャラ、という感じです。

あ、なるほどです！
もしかしたら最高の名前が別であるかもですが、ローカル関数だし全然オッケーな気がしました！
MULTI_CHANGE_VOICEにしました。
unitの方にutilsがあったのでutilsにしました。
値変更にしました。
シンプルなのでそのままで良いと思います
ほぼLGTMかなという気持ちです！！

名称ですが、これだと「オーディオキーがスピーカーを初期化する」という意味に変わりそうです。
ChatGPT https://chat.openai.com/share/95d89a9e-7aee-4869-bcde-9e282d1ff425
initializingSpeakerAudioKeysのが良さそう？
･･･と思ったけどこれ以前からこういう命名規則だったんですね 😇
この機会にえいやで正しくしちゃっていただけると･･･！！
（もちろんそのままでも）
多分ここは複数にする必要はないのと、単数にして利用側でfor回すようにした方が使いやすそうかなと

順番入れ替えの謎変更があるかも
（コンフリクトが起こる確率が多少上がるだけなのでまあそのままでも！）
  
    
      
        Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
                    { dispatch, commit, state },
          
          
            
                    { state, dispatch, commit },
audioKeysWithInitializingSpeaker、が一番正しい気がしたのでそうします。

単数にして利用側でfor回すようにした方が使いやすそうかな

こうするとフリーズするんですよね。違いました

実行してみたらエラーがconsole出力されていました。
npm run typecheck:vue-tscすると変更漏れ箇所がわかるかもです

LGTM！！！！！！！！
いやーーーーーーー実際使ってみるとすごい感動するくらい便利ですね！！！！！！
他の機能もぜひ実装したみ！！！！！！！

node.title: Batu/pipe implementation
node.body:
The execution with and without pipes are working. I just added a check in main function to see if there are pipes or not and create processes accordingly. Redirections are also partially working but I will create another branch for fixing redirections.

Let me know if you see something wrong. :)

nodes.bodyText:
echo 'hello' is working correctly: hello is printed! Which is great!
But echo 'hello' | echo 'hello world' is not working: nothing is printed. Same for just ls. echo 'hello world' | grep 'hello' is also not working and echo 'hello' | cat is also not working! :-(


echo 'hello' | echo 'hello world'
In this case, I realized the problem is with lexer because argument is lost during lexing, because when i run above command, following is the result of the parser

Parsing













|


























echo hello




























echo
but it should be















Parsing













|


























echo hello




























echo hello world    // correction
















ls

It is fixed now the last commit, It was a problem about not checking if the ast_node->args is NULL before joining comand and args in my execute function. Now it is working as expected


echo 'hello world' | grep 'hello'
Same problem with the first one, hello after the grep is lost during lexing


echo 'hello' | cat


Same problem with the first one , cat is lost during the lexing

node.bodyText:
When I run make I get this:
make all
...
gcc -g -Wall -Wextra -Werror -I./include  -I./libft/include -c src/pipes.c -o obj/pipes.o 
src/pipes.c:107:9: error: variable 'path' is used uninitialized whenever 'if' condition is false [-Werror,-Wsometimes-uninitialized]
    if (node->data)
        ^~~~~~~~~~
src/pipes.c:111:26: note: uninitialized use occurs here
    printf("path: %s\n", path);
                         ^~~~
src/pipes.c:107:5: note: remove the 'if' if its condition is always true
    if (node->data)
    ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
src/pipes.c:95:15: note: initialize the variable 'path' to silence this warning
    char        *path;
                     ^
                      = NULL
1 error generated.
make[1]: *** [obj/pipes.o] Error 1
make: *** [re] Error 2


cfr. also screenshot.
Why are these modifications here? @BatuSengezer

I'm not an hast table super expert but I imagine that it's not enough table[hash("PATH")]->value this thing here to be sure you get the content of the PATH variable in the hash table. I mean our environemnt variable are very few so that probably there will be no collision, i.e. there will be only one element in the linked list which starts from the idx [hast("PATH")] of the table array, but it could be that the linked list starting from there has more than one element and we need to check also that the key of the node is "PATH". Isn't it? But I could be completely wrong. @BatuSengezer
What are these numbers?
Why is this (14) here?
Like this!
Now I fixed the issue with make.
Also I think it seems there is modification in lexer because main is ahead 7 commits, a rebase should fix it I think. I will let you know when it is done

Noo, you are right, I need to make an iteration to check if they are there, also I need to take all elements from ht (envp basically), I will keep this in mind  at this when I am pulling all the environment variables for execve function (I will create another branch for this as well)
These are the numbers we splitted all subject topics so I kept the same numbers :)
Same with previous one :)
Ok. Then I'll wait that you at least open an issue in linear so that we don't forget it. Waiting for the link of the issue here. I'm the hardest of the reviewers! :-)
All right! It compiles now!
In the code in that file?
I added some comments in the code but I have also a general question, cause I was trying to test it. With which command should I test it? What it is supposed to do till to this point?
Why is this include here and not in the header file. Is it a choice?
This comment means we are not using this function? I see that it is called one time in minishell.c but that line is commented out.

I add this comment here, cause it is the main/first function of the pipes structure that takes the envp variable. We already talked about the necessity to use our internal representation of the environment variables, but since we execute command with execve  int execve(const char *path, char *const argv[], char *const envp[]); which takes as third argument a bidimensional array, does it make sense to have our variables stored in an hash table?

I had a talk with our friend about the problem and this is what he had to say about the argument: https://chat.openai.com/share/c0457cfa-84b0-4b28-a9cf-c1b72486f2f4.
So it seems we need to convert the hash table to something like the original envp. It suggests to convert it before calling execve and it also wrote some code and suggested some modification. What do you think? @BatuSengezer
When we exit here, we exit abruptly the program without freeing anything?
This makes you the best teammate to push for improving! :)
Yeaah, you are right :) It should be in another file!
Ahahahahaha 🤣
No, actually I forgot about it, thanks for letting me know!

You can test it with any command and any number of pipes including zero, but redirections are not working correctly in some cases so I would suggest not to test it with redirections but you can as well :)
yeaah, right now we are not using it but I was keeping it in case we need it somewhere else, I will remove it at the end
I think that would be nice and I would prefer that, hash table is making it just a bit harder. But it is up to you, if you don't want to change it, I can work with it as well
Yeaah, I will write a free function and put it before each exit
What would you prefer? We can't give anyway the hash table directly in execve as an argument.
Then we need maybe to add a comment like // TODO: free memory before exit
How can we do that? Don't we need to give all the keys to retrieve all of the results from the hash table?
I will do that :)

You didn't read the link with the conversation with the friend, right? As I said in the previous comment we need to convert the hast table into a two dimensional array before feeding it into execve. Cause execve expects a char** as third parameter. But I guess I can do it myself.

Yeaah, I haven't. I thought you sent it in case I want to go deeper. What I thought was converting it into an array after retrieving all the information from the hash table but then why do we even need to create the hash table? Does it help us in any way except it is the way shell works?
We don't need it. It's just cool to have an hash table. Anyway I already opened an issue in linear about it: we can discuss it there as we already do.
LGTM!
